The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility.

TXU Electric's overall approach to accident prevention and risk management is as follows:

TXU Electric is committed to protecting its employees, the public, and the environment from any accidental releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities.  TXU Electric has implemented safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to minimize the risks presented by hazardous materials used at its facilities.  If there is an accidental release, TXU Electric will either provide, or request from others, immediate emergency response to minimize the effect of the release. TXU Electric will also immediately notify the public, through county emergency management agencies, of any actions necessary to ensure public protection.

Your facility and the regulated substances handled.

Monticello Steam Electric Station (MOSES) is an electric generating plant using fossil fuel (coal) as an energy source.  The coal is burned in large boilers to produce steam, which is used as the motive force for the TXU turbine generators. TXU Electric takes great care in reducing emissions from burning coal to the greatest extent possible by injecting. an ammonia/air mixture into the pollution control devices (electrostatic precipitators and baghouses).  The ammonia reacts with sulfur dioxide present in the emission (flue gas) stream and acts to agglomerate the ash creating a larger particle size and improving performance of the pollution control devices.
TXU Electric uses anhydrous ammonia (CAS Number 7664-41-7) at MOSES.  It is purchased as a compressed liquefied gas in bulk from commercial suppliers and fed to vaporizers where the liquid is converted to a gas and then injected into the flue gas streams. There are two separate ammonia systems at MOSES, each with an 18,000 gallon storage tank. Inventory is controlled to a maximum of 84,067 pounds of ammonia in each tank.  This inventory exceeds the

threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds established under the RMP regulations. 

The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s).
The worst-case release scenario.

MOSES has conducted an offsite consequence analysis including a worst-case release scenario.  As required by the RMP regulations, the worst-case scenario is defined as a ten-minute release of the greatest quantity of the regulated substance contained in any single vessel or pipeline.  For MOSES this greatest quantity is the 84,067-pound maximum inventory of the ammonia storage tank.  Consequently, the worst-case release is 8,410 pounds per minute of ammonia for ten minutes.

The regulations require assuming worst-case wind speed and atmospheric conditions that result in the greatest projected impact distance.  A release dispersion model is used to project the distance to an "endpoint" concentration of the released compound.  For the offsite consequence analyses required by the RMP regulations, this endpoint concentration is defined by the Emergency Response Planning Guideline (ERPG-2) values developed by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA).  AIHA defines the ERPG-2 value as, "the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action."  The endpoint (ERPG-2 value) established for ammonia is 0.14 mg/L.

For the rural setting of MOSES, the potential distance to the endpoint concentration for the worst-case release is 4.2 miles.  This distance was obtained from the dispersion modeling software Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres Version 5.2.1 (ALOHA).  ALOHA was developed through a joint effort of the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration as a tool for emergency responders and emergency plannin

g in assessing potential dispersions of hazardous materials. 

There are approximately 1,448 residents within the 4.2-mile radius for the worst-case scenario.  However, if the worst-case release occurred, only a small fraction of these residents that are located downwind of MOSES would be in the affected area.  Other public receptors within the 4.2-mile radius include churches and recreational lakes and park areas.  There are no hospitals, prisons, or major office or industrial areas within this impact area. The only environmental receptor (i.e., national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas; and Federal wilderness areas) within the impact area is Lake Bob Sandlin State Recreation Area.

A major release of the magnitude represented by this worst-case scenario is extremely unlikely because of the robust design of storage tanks and the rigorous maintenance and prevention programs in place at MOSES.  In fact, release reporting databases and industry experience suggest that the worst-case release scenario as defined in the RMP regulations is so unlikely that it should not be used as the basis for emergency planning.  A more reasonable potential release scenario for emergency planning is presented in "The alternative release scenario(s)" section below.

The alternative release scenario(s).
In determining the alternative release scenarios at MOSES, the results of the process hazard analysis (PHA) and the facility's operating history were used. The PHA assessed the likelihood and expected severity of potential accident scenarios.  The selected alternative release scenarios are presented below:

( Alternative Release Scenario 1
The first alternative release scenario involves a vapor release from a pressure relief valve on the storage tank.  This results in a total anhydrous ammonia release of 5,639 pounds over a 1-hour period.

( Alternative Release Scenario 2
The Units 1 & 2 and Unit 3 tanks are equ

ipped with excess flow valves that shut the flow of ammonia if there is a major liquid piping failure or leak.  This scenario considers any small leak or opening in the line that is just small enough to keep the excess flow valve from seating, or less than 90 gpm. This results in a total anhydrous ammonia release of 30,720 pounds over a 1-hour period.

For the rural setting of the MOSES, the potential distances to the endpoint concentration for these alternate release scenarios is 0.2 miles and 0.6 miles, respectively.  The maximum impact from all alternative scenarios modeled is approximately 21 residents within this potential impact area; however, only a small fraction of these residents located downwind of the release would typically be in the affected area.  Other public receptors within the maximum distance include a church and park areas.  There are no hospitals, prisons, or major office or industrial areas within this impact area. There are no environmental receptors (i.e., national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas; and Federal wilderness areas) within the impact area.  As with the worst-case scenario, actual distances and directions vary with terrain and weather conditions.
The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
Under the EPA RMP regulations, three levels of prevention program requirements have been established to roughly match the level of effort to the risk of off-site impacts.  Because the offsite consequence analysis showed that the worst-case release scenario could impact offsite public receptors, and because the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119) is applicable at this facility, TXU Electric's Monticello Steam Electric Station must meet RMP Program 3 Prevention Program requirements for its ammonia processes.  

TXU Electric has a high level of management commitment to personnel safety, public safety, continued reliable operat

in the past five years, TXU Electric's Monticello Steam Electric Station has not had any accidental releases that resulted in injuries or property damage. Under the RMP regulations, all accidental releases of a regulated substance that "resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage" within the past 5 years must be reported.  
The emergency response program
 MOSES has an emergency response program that includes an emergency response plan addressing the EPA RMP-regulated ammonia system operated at the facility.  MOSES' emergency response plan contains:
7 Procedures for informing the Titus County LEPC, Mt. Pleasant Fire Department and the community about accidental releases.
7 Proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental exposures to ammonia gas.
7 Specific procedures for emergency response to either stop the ammonia release and/or evacuate people who could be affected by the release.
 
 MOSES' Emergency Response Program includes the necessary emergency response equipment, personnel, and training to respond to potential releases.  MOSES has procedures for emergency equipment use, inspection, testing, and maintenance.  In addition, MOSES' emergency response plan has been coordinated with the Titus County LEPC.
 
 Planned changes to improve safety
 In TXU Electric's ongoing effort to improve safety and reduce the risk of accidental releases at MOSES, the following changes to the RM Program and the facility have been implemented or are currently planned.  These improvements were identified as risk reduction measures during the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) or were the result of TXU Electric's desire to develop an improved RMProgram and inherently safer processes.
